Award.AwardTitle: Silver nanocluster emitters in nucleic acid assemblies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Elisabeth Gwinn and Deborah Fygenson of the University of California, Santa Barbara are supported by an award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program for research to build understanding of the spectral properties, solution structures and array potential of fluorescent silver clusters that are stabilized within DNA strands and strand assemblies. Tandem HPLC-mass spectrometry with in-line optical spectroscopy will be used to determine how the optical properties of such Ag:DNAs relate to the number of silver atoms and DNA strands contained in the complexes. Double-stranded DNA strut constructs will be developed to hold individual silver clusters in defined geometries, and to support dual clusters in nanoscale proximity. Measurement of diffusion constants, combined with structural modeling, will probe whether incorporation of the clusters grossly disrupts the designed assemblies. Single molecule microscopy will be used to evaluate polarization signatures of dual silver cluster assemblies held in strut-based constructs and to probe whether silver cluster transition moments are oriented by the underlying DNA assembly. To characterize and enable future exploitation of directional optical interactions of such oriented silver cluster moments, spectral and polarization imaging studies will be carried out on silver cluster arrays formed on DNA nanotubes.

Tiny, light-emitting silver clusters that are held within synthetic DNA strands are beginning to emerge in innovative applications for imaging, molecular logic, and selective sensing. Further development is impeded by the current lack of understanding of the cluster sizes and shapes, and of how they interact with the DNA that keeps them stable. This work will build an understanding of how the color and brightness of Ag:DNAs depends on silver cluster sizes and on the DNA surroundings. The development of strategies to hold multiple clusters in nanoscale proximity on DNA constructs will enable tests of whether the orientation of the clusters is stable enough over time to be exploited in directional interactions of arrayed clusters. Such Ag:DNA constructs may impact technology through future use in signaling chemical, mechanical and electronic events; in new probes of biomolecules, and through fluorescence identification of structural perturbations too subtle to identify with existing microscopies. High-school audiences will be exposed to this multi-disciplinary work through UCSB's School for Scientific Thought, in mini-classes developed and taught by graduate student researchers. The emphasis on undergraduate participation in the research will focus on engaging students who transfer to UCSB from California Community Colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: We studied special optical nanomaterials called “AgN-DNA” that we made by wrapping short strands of DNA around small clusters of silver (Ag) containing N = 10-30 atoms. These silver clusters are so small that their properties change dramatically upon addition or removal of just one atom.  Because bare metal clusters tend to stick together, their special physical and chemical characteristics must be protected by attaching molecules to the cluster surface. Such protected metal clusters are exciting for future developments in molecular electronics, biomedical applications, biological imaging and catalysis. Silver clusters are particularly promising for their superior optical properties.  Our experiments indicated that use of DNA as the protecting molecule produces silver clusters with unusual geometries: they are long, thin rod-shaped clusters, in contrast to the globular (nearly spherical) shapes typical of other protected metal clusters. Our experiments showed that the silver clusters in AgN-DNA contain certain special numbers of silver atoms, called “magic numbers”, different from those of globular clusters.  We found that the elongated cluster shapes in AgN-DNA give rise to uniquely desirable optical properties.  We showed that certain AgN-DNA are highly efficient fluorophores, meaning that they readily emit light.  Our experiments established that the colors of the light absorbed and emitted by these clusters has an unusually strong dependence on cluster size, due to the rod shapes of silver clusters in AgN-DNA. We found that the size of these clusters is governed by the particular sequence of the short pieces of DNA that wrap around them.  Our work on the interaction of silver cations, Ag+, with DNA found that for certain base compositions of the DNA strand, Ag+ causes the formation of double-stranded DNA with enhanced thermal and chemical stabilities compared to the canonical Watson-Crick double helix.  This finding is promising for further development of the field of DNA nanotechnology and may ultimately prove important in biomedical manipulation of DNA. Our experiments found both cationic (Ag+) and neutral silver atoms in AgN-DNA, indicating that the silver cations play crucial roles in stabilizing and selecting the cluster structure that is formed by the neutral silver atoms.  In investigations of the effects of adding small nontoxic molecules that can alter the shape of DNA in water, we found that these mild changes in solution conditions shifted the colors of light that the clusters absorb and emit in ways indicating that the silver clusters sense the effects of molecules that are very close to the cluster.  This finding may ultimately help elucidate the special interactions of water molecules, and other small molecules, that assist DNA in performing its natural functions. The remarkable self-assembly properties of DNA, which enable formation of elaborate nanometer-scale scaffolds made of DNA, combine with the remarkable optical properties of silver clusters to hold great promise for achieving precisely arranged patterns of clusters that are held very close together on DNA scaffolds.  This controlled patterning of metal clusters in arrays is important for realizing designer chemical, electronic and optical properties. We made two important steps in this direction. First, we used DNA sequence engineering to prove that silver clusters of different sizes and colors can maintain their individual structures, even in a water solution, when the clusters are held in DNA constructs at separations below 10 nanometers. We then realized arrays of large numbers of identical silver clusters, all with the same number of silver atoms, by attaching these clusters to nanoscale tubes made entirely of DNA. In principle, these same techniques can be applied to realize multi-color, multicluster constructs in diverse, well-controlled patterns on DNA scaffolds. 

Broader Impacts This grant supported the PhD theses of three graduate students, two of them women in fields with low representation of women scientific leaders. The grant supported research experiences for ten undergraduates, four of whom co-authored publications. We recruited five junior transfer students from CA community colleges (CCC) to participate in the research. We developed and taught the class “A Twist on Light: The Underlying Importance of Chirality ” to an audience of 9-12 graders in UCSB’s School for Scientific Thought. The course focused on what chirality is in molecules, its relation to light, and how it plays an important role in our everyday lives and in NSF-funded research on the projects above.
